thread.title: Could Britain's next runaway tech success be one of these start-ups?
thread.title_full: Could Britain's next runaway tech success be one of these start-ups?

title: Could Britain's next runaway tech success be one of these start-ups?
text:
0.00 0.00 
MassChallenge, the largest start-up accelerator in the world, reveals its pick of the UK's emerging talent 
The UK's most exciting technology start-ups have been unveiled by MassChallenge, the growth programme for new entrepreneurs. 
Among the 26 young companies singled out by the accelerator, which provides cash to growing start-ups for no equity stake, are: a high tech womenswear tailor on Savile Row, a manufacturer of emergency baby incubators , and a software provider for the blind. 
These start-ups will pitch to a final judging panel to determine who will win a share of $500,000 (£323,000) cash - part of a $1.5m global pot. The judges include serial entrepreneur Henry Lane Fox and Angels Den founder Bill Morrow, among others. 
Womenswear start-up Gormley & Gamble was founded by 21-year-old Phoebe Gormley last year. The company already boasts a customer list that includes Virgin Money boss Jayne-Anne Gadhia and an unnamed Spanish princess. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) is the only tailor dedicated to womenswear on Savile Row, and uses hi-tech silk printers to create one-off linings for its high-end pieces. 
"We can print your Instagram feed or pictures from a family holiday," said Ms Gormley, who left university to start the business. "We also use technology for pattern cutting that reduces human time and error." 
The company, which charges between £200 and £1,200 for customised clothing, is on target to turn over six figures within its first 18 months trading. "We'd love to win MassChallenge so that we could invest in getting samples made and employ someone to help with back of house," Ms Gormley said. 
Compare and Share (LSE: SHRE.L - news ) , an online directory of sharing economy businesses , was launched two and a half years ago by Benita Matofska, 48. The business helps users to sift through 7,850 websites across 17 categories, from minding your pet to ride-sharing. 
"We have big ambitions to build the go-to brand for the sharing economy," said Ms Matofska. "MassChallenge is a springboard for us." 
GiveVision uses wearable technology to help blind or partially-sighted people to "see" digitally. The start-up uses Google Glass and other hi-tech smartglasses to translate a visual world into an audio stream. 
GiveVision is currently trialling a prototype of its smartglass software with 180 users. "People think it's science fiction but we can use technology to magnify or turn visual information into audio in real-time," said co-founder Elodie Draperi. 
The other shortlisted companies are: BuyerDeck, Cambridge Bio Augmentation Systems, Carbon Analytics, Converge, DOYA Medical, Financial Market Rank, FoPo Food Powder, Glisser, Great Little Place, HelpingB, Live Better With..., MOM Incubators, Preliminal Games, RE-VANA, Renovagen, Resonance, Shoot, Sinclair Fire, twosigmas, Unique Access, Vidsy, World Around Me, and zipcube.com. 
The winner will be announced on October 22 at a gala ceremony in London. 
"These top 26 start-ups are poised to make a tremendous impact across a variety of industries, from transportation to healthcare to robotics," said MassChallenge founder John Harthorne. 
MassChallenge is a not-for-profit organisation, which aims to fund and support emerging technology talent. The programme is funded by sponsors such as NatWest, Unilever (NYSE: UL - news ) , Visa (Xetra: A0NC7B - news ) , IBM (NYSE: IBM - news ) , Media City UK, and Taylor Wessing. 
To date, MassChallenge alumni have raised over $1.1bn in funding. 
These include: Relay Rides, which won $50,000 in 2010 and has gone on to dominate the car-sharing market in the US, securing more than $60m in growth capital to date, and 2014 winner Drinkwell, which won $100,000 for its clean water technology that aims to save 200 million people from drinking arsenic and fluoride-contaminated water in developing countries (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) .
